Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2011 04:57PM amelia2 wrote: Congratulations to all who have finished or about to finish RADS.  I will be starting my 25X on 5 April.  I have planning on 23 March.  I have been reading your thread to know what to expect.  I noticed some have saw or peeling armpit as well as breast area.  Is this because you have had radiation treatment is this area too?  In my initial appointment with my RO I understood I would have radiation just to the breast area. My last radiation is scheduled for 12 May and we have planned a 10 day vacation to Hawaii on 26 May. ( We booked and paid for this before I was diagnosed).   My RO has said I should be OK to go, but I am now uncertain. From your experiences I would value your advice about whether I am being naive about being ready to enjoy a beach type holiday, including swimming so soon after rads.  Will my breast skin still be raw and will I still be very tired two weeks after finishing rads?  Also my last chemo is on 14 March is it likely I will have enough hair cover to go without a scarf by 26 May?
Posts.Title: January 2011 Rads suzieq60 msjag

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2011 02:59AM amelia2 wrote: JulieH - welcome back I worried about you when you were so quiet, sorry you have been so low,  sending you {{{HUGS}}} and good wishes for better days ahead. UTMom -glad you are better and out of hospital, thanks for the tips on staying out, I am having my bloods done tomorrow for nadir so am hoping for good results. Positive thoughts to everyone and much strength to get throught this.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2011 03:27AM amelia2 wrote:
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2011 09:36PM amelia2 wrote: Day 2 after Tx2 and I have no energy to do anything except sit. It is very hot here today. hsgray  So sorry to hear you had such a hard time, home is better, hope you are still improving.  My WBC went down to 2.8 and my neutrophil to <0.1 at my nadir so I was lucky not to get an infection.  I did get a few spots on my legs that looked like staph infections so was imagining the worst, gangrene and amputation.  Imagination gone balistic.  Better now thank goodness.  I wish you well with your recovery as your treatment progresses. I think it is so unfair that on top of all our other SE s we have this hair thing to worry about. JulieH you must look great with your shave hair as your DH said, good for you. tideknott the hair shave party sounds like a fun way to deal with this. suz3 my hair also was like straw before coming out.Yuk. bdavis it is ok to get emotional, losing your hair is a big thing, I have been told that it will come back better than ever but it is managing in the meantime, I bought lots of hats and scarves and now the time to wear them is here I find I do not really like any of them too much on me. baf 4292 I have not bought a wig yet It is 37degrees Celcius here today which is very hot and I have been told that over 30 degrees Celcius they can get sweaty and scratchy so am still holding off.  Also the onco clinic and wig salon advice is that real hair can be too high maintenance for chemo patients as like real hair it needs styling after each wash, whereas synthethic is basically wash, and let it dry.  We have a wigsonwheels service here where they come to your house, the ladies who have used this say it is great, they bring a big selection and are not pushy salespeople, still considering this.   DH has just got home to give me my Neulasta shot.  Best wishes to all, especially those going in for tx this week, and those suffering SE's.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2011 04:23PM amelia2 wrote: Hi everyone It is so good to be able to share the good and not so good with you. Marymeg I totally agree with you about sharing the not so good through these posts as I also do not want to overload the local support with my woes.  It is great how you keep your sense of humour.  Yesterday was a total writeoff for me, like a zombie on day 3.  I did get the bone pain from the Neulasta and the fatigue and nausea was worse. A bit better today. I am trying to work out whether I am up to driving to my art class this afternoon. JulieH and golfergrandma, I was told by the onco nurse that a glass or two of wine is ok while on chemo, but that I probably wouldn't feel like it.  He was right, I tried some but it tasted awful, so I have given up for now.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2011 05:22PM amelia2 wrote: Marymeg -  Happy Birthday and all the best for today. Hope you enjoy Look Good Feel Better.  I received a lovely pamper pack from the McGrath Foundation today which lifted my spirits, hope you get lots of goodies too. ck mom - So sorry you have had to deal with cold and fever on top of everything else Webu  - Hope all goes well with your daughter, it is hard, we all want the best for our kids, I have had my share of worries with my son and he is in his 30's now and I still worry. Happy Day, I struggled to art class yesterday bad day 4, glad I made the effort, something to get out of bed for and shower and get dressed, it was like occupational therapy doing cutting out and pasting bits of paper, I am not at all arty or creative but it was good to get out.  I feel like I am over the worst of tx 2 now Day 5 and thank you all for sharing the positives, it is so good to know we can do this together, and we can beat it, it really helps on the bad days.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2011 01:30AM amelia2 wrote: Hi everyone. I am now on day 16 after my first chemo and am noticing hairs starting to fall out, not handfuls yet but definitely shedding a few.  How long will it take for them all to fall out.  Not sure when to do the buzz cut or shave head.  Going out on Saturday so am wondering if hair will still be there or gone. Also my rash is better. Cool short showers and ice packs helped. I saw my onco yesterday and she said that it is not a common SE, one in ten, so I was just unlucky with it.  She has given me cortisone cream prescription for the next time in case I get it again.  My other SE have not been bad so am not complaining. Also sharing not as sharp vision with other ladies who have posted this SE.  Hope it is temporary.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2011 03:24AM amelia2 wrote: Proud Mom_Wife  I am so pleased you are taking time out to get well. I am taking at least 6 months leave and have been in awe of all those working, and doing exercise and feeling a little inadequate as I have not got the energy to keep juggling all the balls myself.  I agree that your body is the best guide and tells you how much it is capable of and when it says it is tired I rest.   I do gentle exercise, little walks, little swims, I have signed up for gentle yoga for over 40's. Julie H Thank you for your responses, you sound like you are going really well, good luck with your next tx  Today I took the plunge and hair is gone. My gorgeous son had a day off work and came over and took the clippers to my head. He was so gentle.  It is such a relief, now I do not have to worry about it falling out, its gone. Just some stubble left. My first venture into public without my hair is still to come and am thinking about what head covering I will choose. My son thinks I should just go au natural and not worry about scarves or hats at all. I have some nice things planned for the weekend to celebrate the end of the first TCH cycle. My next tx infusion is Monday 31st, and will have Neulasta the following day. I am feeling good at the moment, but expect that there will be a few days after chemo where there will be usual SE, if they are no worse than last time I know I can manage them.  Hoping I avoid the rash this time though.  I am also interested to see how the Neulasta affects me as I did not have this with the 1st tx.  Best wishes to all as you continue with your treatments, and hope your SE are bearable.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2011 02:24PM amelia2 wrote: moe0279 - sorry you are feeling low, be kind to yourself, do not feel guilty about cleaning the house you need to look after yourself to get better, there will be many years after you are better to clean etc, not sure if this is good or bad news, depends on your fondness for cleaning, not my favourite activity.  The good news is we will get through this.  I am glad we have this thread for venting.  I also have a funny burning sensation at the tip of my tongue where it touches my teeth, have been using biotene products, also a mouthwash with a tspn of bicarb in water is not as drying as salt. JulieH - hope you enjoy a lovely Valentine's dinner with your DH.  I had a knock on the door this morning to find a lovely bouquet from the florist, the first time in years my DH has remembered Valentine's Day. We have been married for 37 years. Webu - definitely chemo brain, last Friday I forgot to go to the appointment with my onc.  I keep forgetting names, words and what I am doing.  I get stuck half way in conversations and have forgotten what I was going to say, very annoying. 1Miclon - My DH gave me my first Neulasta shot at home into my tummy , it didn't hurt, just like a mild bee sting for a few seconds, then no pain.  The bone pain came the next day. The week before my TCH #3 and am feeling good, have made a to do list, will see how many I can action before the next knock out.  Happy Valentine's Day everyone.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2011 07:11PM amelia2 wrote: Science Girl Hope you are starting to feel better.  My round 2 was also worse than round 1, my onc had led me to expect that round 1 set the bar and next tx would be if not better then no worse than round 1.  I wonder if it is the neulasta, I did not get this with #1.  I am day 8 after #2 and feeling much better now, but am also fearful of #3 because of the two really bad days with round 2. Also struggling with the hair loss thing. My buzz now looks mangey with growing bald patches. I am scared to shave it in case it goes really itchy.  We have just come out of a record heat wave, 7 days straight with temperatures over 30 C, covering my head just made me hotter.  We went to a show on Saturday night, I wore a scarf and I tried not to feel self conscious, as the only person in the theatre with my head covered. I didn't win that one. With this heat a wig is not an option for me.  It is cooler today and last night was the first night I got some proper sleep in a week. I  try to stay positive.  Doing chemo is hard.  I tell myself my cancer is gone.  They took it out when they operated and threw it in the bin.  The chemo will stop it ever coming back, so even though it is hard it will be worth it.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2011 02:27PM amelia2 wrote:
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2011 05:47PM amelia2 wrote: slcst! - Love the pirate cat card comments. Very funny. Think of it every time I am out and about with my scarf.  Hope you are feeling ok after tx3.  My hair looks like a world map, large white oceans with shrinking dark islands. The dark bits are about half inch long and it keeps shedding. Am worried about shaving it off as I got folliculitis where I shaved my legs.   Maybe after tx3 on Monday it may all finally fall out? JulieH - hope you are recovering and feeling better. Anniemomofthree - good luck with your next tx on Monday.  It is funny but I am feeling so anxious about the bad days that follow even though I know I will only feel really bad on day 3 and day 4 if it follows previous pattern. My chemo brain is getting worse, forgetting everything.  Have been to my GP twice now to get referals for my oncologists and then about a week later I suddenly remember I forgot to ask for them.  Will have to tattoo on the back of my hand so I remember next time.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2011 05:04AM amelia2 wrote: Hello everyone, had TX #3 today, TCH, only one more after this, then herceptin for the rest of the year.  At the moment I have the steroid fueled energy and not feeling sleepy syndrome, but otherwise feeling ok so far.   Question - My onc suggested that I taper off the steroid tablets, to avoid the Day 3 and Day 4 total collapse.  I have been taking 2 tablets day before, 2 tablets day of, and 2 tablets the day after, then crash on Day 3.  She said I could take 1 tablet Day 3 and 1 tablet Day 4 to give the body time to adjust and maybe have a gentler landing.  Has anyone else tried this and has it helped? I am also a bit worried in case extending the steroids increases the sleepless nights. Christine47 - Welcome and sorry you have to be here.  I find this board a great support with lots of helpful info and a lovely caring group. bdavis - I also have the heartburn from when I start the pre chemo steroids for about a week to ten days. Asked my onc today and she prescribed Ranoxly 2x a day while symptoms last, this is the same as Zantac, same chemicals different brand. I have only taken one tablet so far, will let you know if they work.  slsct - I also used Senna once, and ended up with diarhrea. Not sure I really needed the senna but I was terrified about the constipation as I really suffered with this when I had my hysterectomy, ended up in hospital which eventually produced a result, know what you are going through, it is not nice.  I know this won't help you this round but for the future, my oncology nurse suggested I start taking softeners one or two days before the chemo as she said that constipation is more likely and more difficult to deal with than the diarhrea.   I take a fibre drink Metamucil, before chemo.  I don't know if you have that over there, it comes as a powder and you stir a spoonful into water.  I have not suffered from constipation with the chemo so it may be working.  It says on the label it is not recommended for chemical induced constipation, so I would not take it after chemo, only before as a prep. I also have lots of fluids and fruits with high water content on the days before the chemo days. BIG {{{{{{{{{ To everyone suffering SE's this week }}}}}}}}}
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2011 10:47PM amelia2 wrote: AimeeMac - I am starting radiation on 4 April 25 X and am also starting to think about this, I have been reading the January RADS thread, but most of those ladies are done or nearly done with their radiation. I think a Starting RADS in April discussion board would be good.  Will you start it?  Let us know. I still have one more chemo to go 14 March.  Looking forward to the end of chemo, and hopefully the return of hair.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2011 07:43PM amelia2 wrote: Hi Julie Hope all goes well with your chemo. Your diagnosis sounds similar to mine. Lumpectomy 1 Dec, re excision 22 Dec to get clear margin, healing well. My first infusion was 10 Jan with TCH X 4 cyles every three weeks, then Herceptin for rest of the year at 3 week intervals.  The SE mainly very tired,bit nauseous.  On day 4 after the chemo I developed a very itchy rash like hives on my chest and shoulders. The onco clinic said try claritin but that hasn't really helped.  It is mid summer here and the heat and humidity make it worse. I have been told the rash should go away in about a week, has anyone else had this experience? I got my hair cut very short in the week before chemo and this has been good as it is easy, a bonus when tired and not feeling great. I am on antibiotics to counter infections, definitely feeling better this week than last week.  Not sure if I will be able to wear a wig, have tried several but they have not felt comfortable.  My hairdresser has been very kind and loaned me two wigs and i have stocked up on scarves.  Not looking forward to losing my hair. So sorry to all suffering through this and hope you all feel better soon.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2011 03:38AM amelia2 wrote: hi everyone  I had my #2 TCH today, the nurses at the onco clinic are lovely and do a great job.  Feeling good so far, better than with #1, please let it continue this way.  Short walk after dinner across Seacliff Bridge, lovely cool breeze off the water, it was hot today, forecast tomorrow hotter, I actually appreciated being able to spend the day in the air conditioning in the onco clinic. HA! Neulasta tomorrow. My DH will give me the shot.  Lucky I have lots of tummy flab to put it in. Will let you know how I go with SE I feel for all of you who are really suffering with tummy upsets.  I found a small amount of peeled grated apple eaten slowly worked for my heartburn.  JulieH  I checked and the onco said the rash was most likely from taxotere not herceptin. Lorenar  Biotene Toothpaste and Mouthwash have been good for me, also my onco nurse told me a teaspoon of bicarbonate of soda in a glass of water works just as well as a mouthwash and I have used this several times a day and found it good too. Just had a phone call from a cousin in Germany to see how I am going.  He made me laugh so I feel good now and will go to bed, hopefully to sleep. Positive thoughts and good luck to all with you treatments this week.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2011 02:05AM amelia2 wrote: A positive for me.  Tonight after dinner I walked down to the beach with my DH and immersed myself in the South Pacific Ocean. Amazing. Life is good.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2011 04:01PM amelia2 wrote: Beckie What a fun way to lose your hair. You make bald beautiful.  Your smile is a winner, what a great support group you have!!  All the best for Friday.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2011 04:47PM amelia2 wrote: UT Mom - re nails  I have been using revitanail hardener 2 coats and 1 coat magenta colour nailpolish. I use a non acetone gentle varnish remover. I redo about once a week and massage nail and cuticle cream then and use sorbolene cream several times a day on my hands and nails.  Also wear rubber gloves when washing or cleaning. So far they are going ok, maybe a bit softer, slightly discoloured but hanging on. My oncology clinic provides iced gloves during the taxotere infusion. Tammy - I also saw the no cure thread and found it unsettling.  I am thinking positive, like you I believe I will be better after my treatment is completed.  The cancer will be gone and I will live in wellness.  There is nothing to be gained from thinking any other way. Good for you that you will take your trip with your DH, hope you have a wonderful holiday. Before I was diagnosed my DH and I booked and paid for 10 day flight to Hawaii at the end of May, a vacation and also to attend a wedding, our dear friends son is getting married on Maui.  Now I am so undecided whether to go or not. My oncologists are also encouraging me to go, but I am worried about 2 things, I will be only one week out of radiation, so am concerned about skin issues and fatigue, and I will still have no hair and worry if this will stop me getting into and enjoying all the celebrations and activities, I will leave it to the last minute to make a decision on that one.  Maybe after I start my rads in April I will have a better idea of the SE. Kim - So happy for you that your PET results were good Steroid Advice, thank you to all of you who commented on your steroid regimes, I hadn't realised they were all so different.  After reading these, this time after chemo I reduced to the one tablet the day after chemo, now on Day 3 and feeling ok, not as knocked out, but just a little more naueous but managing.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2011 05:50PM amelia2 wrote: Tammy - Well done, happy for you that you have got through AC.  It is good that you can take your vacation in Jamaica, and that you can wear your bikini. I am interested in the type of scarves you have ordered and where you got them from because I am still thinking about Hawaii at the end of May.  Some of the scarves I have are very hot to wear and I will need to get a few new ones if we do go. JulieH - Hope you are starting to feel better, if you are still feeling exhausted after the weekend it would be good if you could take a bit of time to rest and recuperate. Look after yourself. slcst12 - I had low vitamin D levels before BC diagnosis and had been taking Vitamin D supplements on my doctor's recommendation for over 12 months prior.  My onc told me to stay on these through out chemo, although she asked me to stop other supplements. I never thought to ask whether the vitamin D deficiency was a cause or effect of BC.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2011 08:01PM amelia2 wrote:
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2011 12:12AM amelia2 wrote: Hi everyone.  I have not posted in a little while but wanted to share my post chemo euphoria. Hurray!!!  had my last chemo infusion today- TC#4. So happy to have that behind me. Expect I will have a couple of days with SE's but as this is the last I am sure I can manage.  Tiredness has been steadily increasing as I have got to this last chemo.  I will be starting RADs on 5 April for 25 treatments daily and I have heard this also can be fatiguing.  I think they like to give you a little break after chemo before RADS to get the toxins out of your system and give you a chance to recover you blood levels. This is from my RO.  I am on Herceptin for the remainder of the year with infusion every 3 weeks but my onc has said that there is minimal SE from herceptin nothing like chemo SE. Keeping my fingers crossed that she is right. I would like to thank all the wonderful women on this thread for sharing the journey, the good and the not so good, their words of encouragement, wisdom, the companionship, just knowing that you are not alone in going through this is such a great support.  I wish you all the very best with your ongoing treatments. I am sorry I do not have the energy for personal messages at the moment.  So ... Congratulations to all who have finished chemo.  And to everyone celebrating birthdays, anniversaries and vacations enjoy and enjoy many more in the years to come. Good luck and best wishes to all.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward
